description: Zero-Noise Extrapolation (ZNE) is one of the most widely used quantum error mitigation techniques. The core idea is deceptively simple: if we can controllably increase the noise in a quantum circuit, we can measure expectation values at several noise levels and then extrapolate back to the zero-noise limit.

The technique was independently proposed by Temme et al. and Li & Benjamin in 2017. It has since become a workhorse of near-term quantum computing, featuring prominently in IBM's 127-qubit experiments (Kim et al., 2023).

The key assumption is that the expectation value \(\langle O \rangle\) depends smoothly on the noise rate \(\lambda\). By evaluating \(\langle O \rangle\) at noise levels \(c_1 \lambda, c_2 \lambda, \ldots, c_M \lambda\) (where \(c_i \geq 1\) are scale factors), one fits a model \(f(\lambda)\) and extrapolates to \(f(0)\).
how_it_works: Choose a set of noise scale factors \(\{c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_M\}\) with \(c_1 = 1\) (the base noise level).
For each scale factor \(c_i\), amplify the circuit noise to level \(c_i \lambda\). Common methods include unitary folding (inserting \(G G^\dagger\) pairs), pulse stretching, or identity insertions.
Execute the scaled circuit and measure the expectation value \(\langle O \rangle_{c_i \lambda}\).
Fit the data \(\{(c_i \lambda, \langle O \rangle_{c_i \lambda})\}\) to a model (polynomial, exponential, or Richardson) and extrapolate to \(\lambda = 0\).

key_equations.label: Linear extrapolation
key_equations.latex: \langle O \rangle_0 \approx a + b \cdot 0 = a, \quad \text{from linear fit } \langle O \rangle_\lambda = a + b\lambda

bias_variance.notes: Higher extrapolation order reduces bias but increases variance exponentially. Richardson extrapolation eliminates bias up to order M but amplifies statistical noise through large alternating-sign coefficients.

advantages: No detailed noise model required â€” only the ability to scale noise controllably
Simple to implement; compatible with any quantum hardware platform
Can be combined with other techniques (e.g., Pauli twirling + ZNE)
disadvantages: Bias from mismatch between assumed extrapolation model and true noise dependence
Variance grows exponentially with extrapolation order (Richardson coefficients alternate in sign)
Noise amplification methods (e.g., folding) may introduce different noise than simply scaling the base noise
Does not help if noise dependence is non-smooth or non-monotonic
use_cases: Variational algorithms (VQE, QAOA) on near-term processors
IBM 127-qubit Ising model experiments (Kim et al., 2023)
Composition with dynamical decoupling or Pauli twirling as a preprocessing step
